MicroReport User Guide 
Android Version 2.0 
PDF version: http://people.ucsc.edu/~cmbyrd/AndroidUserGuide.pdf 

MicroReport is a mobile app that allows community members to report microaggressions they experience and to view reports of others. Microaggressions are subtle slights and indignities based on an identity like race, gender, or sexual orientation. MicroReport provides a way for individuals to better cope with and understand microaggressions. 

Registration 
The first time you open MicroReport after installing or re-installing it, you will be asked to register your device. Your name and email address are required. This information is stored on a password-protected server that only the research team has access to. Reports are displayed with no identifying information. If you are re-installing the app, you should use the same email address and select "Register New Device" when prompted. 

Home 
The home screen displays the map of microaggressions in your community. You can zoom in and out using pinch gestures and pan using swipes to see different parts of the map. A large number of reports in one area will cluster if you zoom out. 

Click on a marker to read the report from that location. In landscape view, you can see a list of all the reports and click on an item to pan to that marker on the map. 

Tap the refresh icon to update the map at any time. 

Click the New Report button to submit a microaggression report. 

Submitting a Report 
In the description field, say what happened, who was involved (without giving any names or identifying information) and how you felt about it. 

If you have your location turned on, you can click the "Use current location" checkbox to automatically record your location. Otherwise, use the drop-down menu to select a building on campus or type in the name of another location. 

If you don't use your location or select a building, your report will automatically appear at the center of campus. 

Optionally, tell us what identities you think the microaggression was related to and how much the incident bothered you. 

Click "Submit" to post your report to the map. Your report will be immediately visible. 

Navigation 
Swipe from the left side of the screen or click the navigation icon in the top left to open the navigation menu. Click on a screen name to go to that screen. 

Good News 
The Good News page features study updates and submitted content. Click on an item to read the full post in your web browser. You can submit resources and affirmations to the research team at microreport-goodnews-group@ucsc.edu. 

We'll post: 
* Campus events 
* Local events 
* Information about supportive or interesting resources 
* Affirmations and positive messages 

We will not post news articles, promotions for commercial services, neutral or negative posts, or any information that could identify an individual. 

Notifications 
About once a day, MicroReport will check for new Good News and notify you if there are any updates. You can disable notifications by going to Settings | Apps | MicroReport and unchecking the box that says "Show notifications". 

Get Help 
This page is a list of campus resources if you need support. 

Give Feedback 
Use this form to send us any feedback about the study or the app. 

Study Website 
This will take you to the main website for the study in your web browser. 

End User License Agreement 
http://people.ucsc.edu/~cmbyrd/MicroReport_EULA.html

How to report a microaggression: 
1. Click the marker icon. 

2. Fill in as much information as you are comfortable with. In the "What happened" section, it is best to include where you are (i.e., classroom, bike path, dining hall), the main actors, your emotional reactions, and how the situation was resolved (if it was). 

3. DO NOT include any information that could be used to identify others or yourself, such as names or specific titles. Even information like "my psych professor" or "my CA" could be used to narrow down the particular person in certain locations. It is best to generally say "my professor", "a staff member", or "another student". 

DO include the group membership of the person if it helps explain the microaggression. For example, "a white student" or "a male staff member". Be careful about including information about yourself as well. Instead of saying that you are a resident in a particular building, you might just say that you are a student in Oakes or College 9. 

4. Use the Hate/Bias Reporting System if you want a response. The goal of the study is just to track microaggressions. If you would like a response from the administration or want to make sure an event is more widely known, go to ReportHate.ucsc.edu and submit a report. 

Remember that we are interested in the event as you experience it. It's ok if you're not sure the event was a microaggression or if others don't have the same reaction that you do. If you need additional support, contact us or one of the organizations below: 

What is the goal of the beta-test? 
The goal is to test an app that can provide more information about when and where microaggressions happen. We are asking you to report any microaggressions you experience this quarter, on or off-campus. You are not required to report and you can withdraw from the study at any time. Please inform the research team as soon as possible if you no longer want to participate. 

What are microaggressions? 
Microaggressions are subtle insults directed toward minority group members. They can be conscious or unconscious, and verbal or non-verbal. 

My app crashed! What do I do? 
If you can get the app working, send a bug report through the Give Feedback page. Tell us as much information about what happened and how you tried to get the app working again. For example, what state the device was in when it crashed (did you have internet access?, did you just reboot?). Also tell us the content of any error messages you saw. If you can't get the app to work, email us at cmbyrd@ucsc.edu. 

Some suggestions for getting the app to work are: 
-Clear the app cache (Settings | Apps | MicroReport | Clear cache) 
-Restart your device 
-Uninstall the app. If you uninstall the app, you will need to contact us for a new installation file.


What if I have another question? 
Use the "Give Feedback" form to report problems with the app or post general comments. If you would like to contact the research team directly, contact Dr. Christy Byrd at cmbyrd@ucsc.edu or (831) 459-3970.
